sub_topic: The study of the properties of the Higgs boson in different decay modes.
message_1: What is the probability of the Higgs boson decaying into two photons or two Z bosons, given its mass and energy, and how do these probabilities compare to each other and to the predicted values from the Standard Model?
message_2:
The Higgs boson, discovered at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in 2012, has a mass of approximately 125 GeV/c². The probabilities of the Higgs boson decaying into different particles are given by their branching ratios, which are predicted by the Standard Model of particle physics.

The branching ratio for the Higgs boson decaying into two photons (γγ) is approximately 0.0023, or 0.23%. This means that, out of 1000 Higgs bosons produced, about 2 or 3 will decay into two photons.

The branching ratio for the Higgs boson decaying into two Z bosons (ZZ) is approximately 0.026, or 2.6%. This means that, out of 1000 Higgs bosons produced, about 26 will decay into two Z bosons.

Comparing these probabilities, the Higgs boson is more likely to decay into two Z bosons than into two photons. However, both of these decay channels are relatively rare compared to other decay channels, such as the Higgs boson decaying into a pair of bottom quarks (with a branching ratio of about 58%).

The observed branching ratios at the LHC experiments (ATLAS and CMS) are consistent with the predictions from the Standard Model, providing further evidence for the validity of the model. However, physicists continue to search for deviations from the Standard Model predictions, which could hint at new physics beyond the Standard Model.
